abstract: Reservoir siltation surveys facilitate the quantification of the mean area-specific sediment yield (SSY) of catchments for decadal and longer time spans. This requires information on the volume (VS) and dry bulk density (dBD) of reservoir deposits, the period of time (TR) during which they were accumulated, the reservoir sediment trap efficiency (TE) and the catchment area (A). For the calculation of the catchment-wide average rate of erosion by water (E), the sediment delivery ratio (SDR) of the catchment needs to be estimated. Each step in this workflow represents a potential source of uncertainty. Here, we explore the extent to which individual error sources contribute to uncertainties in SSY and E values. Mean SSY and E values are inferred for small to medium-sized catchments (≤100 km2) of 15 small (≤350 × 103 m3) intermittently dry reservoirs located in the southern Kruger National Park and observation periods of 30 to 65 yr. Mean relative uncertainties of resulting SSY and E values amount to ±21% and ±46% at the 95% confidence level, respectively. Uncertainties in SSY values arise mainly from the TE estimation (mean fractional uncertainty contribution of 64%), while the SDR estimation is the major cause (79%) for uncertain E values. Uncertainties in the determination of VS and dBD values are rather unimportant, contributing together <30% and <6% to the uncertainty of SSY and E values on average, respectively. Conclusions are drawn regarding reasonable surveying and sampling strategies.

author_highlights.sentence: Reservoir siltation surveys (N = 15) are carried out in the Kruger National Park.
Mean sediment yield and erosion rates are quantified for the reservoir catchments.
The importance of various sources of uncertainty is analyzed.
Conclusions are drawn concerning opportune surveying and sampling strategies.

body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: Core ring and liner samples were weighed and oven-dried at 105 °C following standard protocols (Burt and Soil Survey Staff, 2014) to determine the dBD and the water content (in wt% relative to the wet mass).
body_text.title: Determination of the dry bulk density (dBD)

body_text.sentence: The catchment area of the reservoirs (Fig. 1b) has been previously assessed by Baade and Schmullius (2015) based on six different elevation models (DEMs).
body_text.title: Determination of the catchment size (A)

body_text.sentence: The problem of fluid intrusion that occurs when the clods are submerged to ascertain the clod volume has been previously described (Burt and Soil Survey Staff, 2014, p. 108) and may be circumvented by sealing the clods with semi-permeable plastic lacquer (Brasher et al., 1966).
body_text.title: Low fractional uncertainty arising from the determination of the dry bulk density (dBD)

body_text.sentence: Subsurface samples were recovered alternatively with core rings or a liner sampler (0.3 m; Ø: 50 mm) using a sampling kit with extension rods (Eijkelkamp®).
body_text.title: Determination of the dry bulk density (dBD)

body_text.sentence: Reservoir deposits show a wedge-shaped distribution in all investigated reservoirs, i.e., the sediment thickness is highest close to the dam and decreases steadily towards the reservoir inlet and the shorelines.
body_text.title: Water storage capacity (C) and volume of reservoir deposits (VS)

body_text.sentence: For a few reservoirs the uncertainty is considerably larger.
body_text.title: Duration of sediment accumulation (TR)

body_text.sentence: The overall mean E value for all study sites amounts to 120 ± 50 t km−2 yr−1 (Cl95) (Table 3).
body_text.title: Minimum catchment-wide rates of erosion by water (Emin), mean area-specific sediment yield (SSY), and best estimates for catchment-wide average rates of erosion by water (E)

body_text.sentence: In this study, the absolute uncertainty (δdBD) of the mean dBD is <0.1 g cm−3 for all reservoirs where ≥20 samples were collected.
body_text.title: Low fractional uncertainty arising from the determination of the dry bulk density (dBD)

body_text.sentence: The analysis of survey data reveals present-day water storage capacities (CS) varying from 3700 ± 100 m3 to 312,400 ± 4200 m3 for the investigated reservoirs (Table 2).
body_text.title: Water storage capacity (C) and volume of reservoir deposits (VS)

body_text.sentence: In the reconnaissance survey, site-specific mean dBD values were ascertained from unsealed clod samples that were collected from side walls of excavation pits.
body_text.title: Low fractional uncertainty arising from the determination of the dry bulk density (dBD)

body_text.sentence: Comparing the findings of this study with results from the reconnaissance survey (Baade et al., 2012) elucidates that limited field data are sufficient to determine VS values with an uncertainty of less than ±30%, given that valid assumptions can be made about the geometry of the sedimentary infill.
body_text.title: Conclusions

body_text.sentence: Bedload from tributaries is deposited close to the reservoir inlets and consists mainly of sand and gravel.
body_text.title: Study area

body_text.sentence: All DTMs are based on triangular irregular network (TIN) interpolation carried out with the software ArcGIS 10.4 (ESRI, 2015).
body_text.title: Determination of the water storage capacity (C) of the reservoir and the volume of reservoir deposits (VS)

body_text.sentence: The period of time (TR) during which the reservoir deposits were accumulated starts with the year of dam construction (TC) and ends with the year of surveying or dam decommissioning (TS).
body_text.title: Duration of sediment accumulation (TR)

body_text.sentence: The survey in 2016 revealed a maximum sediment thickness of 3.4 m close to the dam.
body_text.title: Low fractional uncertainty arising from the determination of the volume of reservoir deposits (VS)

body_text.sentence: Since TS is known, this implies a low uncertainty of ±1 yr for most TR values.
body_text.title: Duration of sediment accumulation (TR)

metadata.title: Inferring mean rates of sediment yield and catchment erosion from reservoir siltation in the Kruger National Park, South Africa: An uncertainty assessment
